DEBATE.TITLE: CONSULTATIONS ON THE NATIONAL AGENDA FOR WOMEN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Consultations on the National Agenda for Women 1986. I seek leave to make a statement relating thereto, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

In November 1985, the Prime Minister made a statement in the Parliament outlining the Government's preliminary thinking on the content of a National Agenda for Women. The Government decided to develop a National Agenda to ensure that efforts made to improve the status of women during the United Nations Decade for Women, which ran from 1976 to 1985, were continued. The National Agenda will provide a basis for Government action to further the status of women as we move towards the year 2000.

In the Prime Minister's statement, he put forward a number of proposals on ways in which the Government might help ensure the full and equal participation of women in Australian society. He announced some important policy initiatives, such as the introduction of affirmative action legislation to guarantee fair and equal opportunity for women in the paid work force and the development of a national women's health policy.

The Prime Minister also pointed to areas where obstacles or prejudices still discourage or inhibit women from participating in society to the full, and where the Government believed that further action was warranted.

At the same time, the Prime Minister invited Australian women to have a say in the development of the National Agenda for Women. I led an extensive series of consultations with women all around Australia and in all walks of life last year, with the assistance of the National Women's Consultative Council.

It is with much pleasure that I today present to the Parliament a report on these consultations. Its title-Setting the Agenda-is evidence that the Government is committed to taking into account the views women in Australia have put forward in the development of the Agenda. I would first like to place on record my thanks to those women who took part in the consultations. It is estimated that more than 25,000 women participated in the process, through completing a questionnaire, taking part in meetings and conferences or making submissions themselves or on behalf of women's organisations.
Substantial agreement on the importance of several issues, particularly the need for equality of opportunity, showed that many major concerns are common to a large number of women in Australia.
I would now like to point to the major concerns and priorities identified during the consultations.

The importance attributed to education for women and girls commonly centred on its role in providing choice about future vocations or occupations. In June last year, an interim National Policy and Plan of Action for the Education of Women and Girls was endorsed by all State and Territories, with the exception of Queensland. When finalised, the national policy will provide a focus and a framework for future action on the education of women and girls by Commonwealth and State authorities. The need for post-school transitional training to facilitate the entry of young women into the paid work force, and for retraining opportunities for women to gain new skills or to update their vocational knowledge were identified as areas requiring further attention.

Issues associated with women's participation in the paid work force were mentioned in most of the submissions or reports of meetings which were received, and women responding to the questionnaire identified work-related matters as among the more important issues on the draft Agenda. These issues included the continued prevalence of occupational segregation, employment conditions such as working hours and leave provisions, and the particular difficulties faced by women who combine full time paid work with caring for a family.

Now that the Affirmative Action legislation is in place, women can expect to face fewer obstacles to achieving their full potential in their working lives. As a result of this higher education institutions and the larger private sector organisations will systematically examine their employment practices to identify and remove explicit or hidden elements which can limit women's opportunities for employment or promotion.

It was apparent that most women work in the home caring for their families from time to time throughout their lives, most often for periods when their children are young. The status and image of women who work full time in the home emerged as a significant area of concern. Many women felt that the value of the contribution made by them to the family and the community is not sufficiently recognised, and that they often suffer from poor self-esteem and isolation. The extent and importance of women's voluntary work in the community and in caring for the aged and disabled was also highlighted during the consultations.

Not surprisingly, child care emerged as one of the most important issues for the Agenda. Women commented on the availability of child care, the variety of care available, and on the costs of care. The Government is proud of its efforts to increase substantially the availability of child care places, which have more than doubled over the last four years. But clearly much still needs to be done.

Questions related to income security were a primary focus of many submissions. Common concerns related to the number of families and women who live in poverty, the question of maintenance payments, the financial position of single and dual income families with children, family allowances and the discrimination against women evident in certain superannuation arrangements. The Government is now considering the findings of the Social Security Review, which has to date focused on financial assistance to families with children, including sole parent families. Last week, the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, announced the Government's plans concerning the establishment of new arrangements for child support payments by non-custodial parents. These measures will improve the financial circumstances of many sole parent families.

Violence against women and children emerged as a priority concern for women. The increased funding which the Government has provided for women's refuges since it has been in office has enabled more women to leave violent domestic situations and to go with their children to a safe place. Last year, the Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, introduced the ACT Domestic Violence Ordinance 1986 and related legislation to provide greater protection for the victims of domestic violence-who are women as well as children-in the Australian Capital Territory. Similar legislation has also been introduced in a number of the States.

The way in which many advertisements continue to portray women in an unrealistic manner was highlighted, as was the still apparent tendency for women's achievements to be down-played or overlooked by the news media.

A number of participants maintained that a preventive and holistic approach to women's health was a cornerstone to achieving overall improvement for women's health in their various stages of life. Much comment focused on aspects of women's reproductive health, on childbirth and on child nurturing. Other concerns included occupational health and safety and aspects of women's mental health.

Access to appropriate and affordable housing was a priority concern for many women, particularly those who are sole parents, who are on low incomes or who are old. It is also a priority of this Government, which has provided an increased level of funding to enable State housing authorities to increase their stock of public housing.

There was widespread recognition of the needs of groups of women who often face additional disadvantages in relation to their participation in society. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, women from non-English speaking backgrounds, women with a disability, sole parents, young women, older women and women living in rural or remote areas have special needs and face additional difficulties in obtaining access to services or in participating to the full in all spheres of activity.

Other issues raised included the importance of consultation and the level of women's participation in decision making in all spheres of activity. The National Agenda consultations have demonstrated the enormous contribution that women themselves can make to the development of appropriate policies and programs. Through the National Women's Consultative Council and other consultative processes, we will ensure that the effective communication channels between Government and women in the community are maintained.

It is clear from this very brief summary of the concerns raised during the consultations that Australian women are looking to Government to continue and enhance its efforts to provide an environment in which their status and levels of participation can grow. The National Agenda for Women will be the foundation on which policies to realise these expectations will be planned and built up to the year 2000.

When the Prime Minister made his Parliamentary statement in November 1985, he was pleased to note that the Opposition substantially agreed with the direction of the Government's thinking for future action to advance the status of women in Australia.

The vote in the House of Representatives on the Equal Employment Opportunity Bill last week, however, has obviously called into doubt the Opposition's commitment in this very important area. The Liberal Party in casting off the work which its then spokesperson, Senator Peter Baume, helped to initiate, shows how the dictates of political opportunism guide its actions.

It is my sincere hope however, and doubtless that of the majority of Australian women, that we can once again secure the high level of bipartisanship that the National Agenda for Women truly deserves.

Work towards finalising the Agenda is well advanced, and I will be announcing it later this year. I commend the report on the consultations to the Senate. It is indeed a fair and detailed representation of the mainstream views of many thousands of our fellow citizens and as such it stands in marked contrast to the extremism which on this and other issues threatens to engulf members opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper which has been tabled by the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) is a report on consultations on the National Agenda for Women. The statement, of course, deals with the contents of that report. The Opposition welcomes the report that has been prepared, which was initiated by the statement the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in the Parliament in November 1985 in which he set out the Government's policy in relation to the preparation of this National Agenda for Women. When that statement was made in the Parliament in November 1985 the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made a major statement on behalf of the Opposition in relation to our policy on and attitude to the question of the status of women and the plans which the Government had in mind. I would like to quote some of the words that the Leader of the Opposition uttered in the House of Representatives on that occasion. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National parties are committed to an effective equality of status for women. We recognise the changes which have occurred and which affect the lifestyles of many women in Australia. We too share very much the goal expressed in the Prime Minister's remarks that we should desire to give greater choice to women in Australia.

Indeed, the theme of those remarks, that of greater choice-which is a major feature of Liberal-National Party philosophy and policies which are being developed in all areas of government-has a very special application in relation to the women of Australia.

The report on the consultations on the National Agenda for Women which has been tabled today shows the value of the work which has been done by those who have been engaged in conducting these consultations. I particularly congratulate the convenor of those groups that conducted these consultations because, as the statement that the Minister has tabled indicates, there has been agreement on the importance of a number of issues which have emerged from these consultations.

As the Leader of the Opposition said so clearly in November 1985-remarks which I reaffirm on behalf of the Opposition-the Liberal-National parties have in government, as well as in opposition, a very proud record in regard to the question of the status of women in Australia. Although this is certainly not recognised by the Minister in this statement, I think it is worth reminding honourable senators that in fact it was the coalition Government which in 1976 established the Office of Child Care. It was that same Government which in 1976 introduced the family allowance, recognising for the first time in Australia in clear terms the importance of a separate income for women even though they were not in the work force. It provided a direct payment to women. I think the significance of the family allowance is that it is an outstanding example of the very important transfer of independence, from a tax deduction for the wage earner-in most cases the husband-to the hands of the wife and mother in the family situation. That fundamental feature of the family allowance is still of the greatest importance to a large number of women in Australia, even though there has been in the last decade a great increase in the number of women in the work force.

One important matter that has been identified by these consultations and which is set out in this statement is the need to recognise the extent and importance of women who work full time in the home. Senator Ryan's statement acknowledges that this emerged as a significant area of concern for Australian women. It also acknowledged the extent and importance of women's voluntary work in the community and in caring for the aged and disabled. That was another feature which was highlighted in these consultations.

The report also sets out some of the other major concerns and priorities which were identified throughout these consultations. The first that was acknowledged and identified was the importance attributed to education for women and girls. That was seen as vitally important in providing choice in regard to their future-the choice either to enter the work force full time or enter it for a period before embarking upon marriage and a family and, very likely, returning to the work force at a later stage. That part of the report noted the importance of post-school transitional training to facilitate that entry into the work force. Of course, that is not unique to women by any means, but the acquiring of technical skills and their right to those technical skills-the same right of any person in the community-is still of great significance to them.

The statement also noted the importance of retraining opportunities for women. This, of course, is no doubt of general importance as well, but is of very special importance to women who have left the work force for a period when their families are young and who want to return to the work force at a later stage. Women may want to acquire new skills, or those with professional skills may want to bring those skills up to date to enable them to go back to their professional work. That is not surprising to the Opposition. Indeed, it is clearly in line with our whole approach to education, our education policies and, particularly, the great importance that we attach in our policies to the availability of choice of education and educational opportunities. We are certainly in a very strong position, in regard to our education policies, to meet that major concern which has been identified by women throughout these consultations.

The statement also noted concern about the continued prevalence of occupational segregation and employment conditions in general-matters such as working hours, no doubt the length of working hours, the actual arrangement of working hours, and leave provisions. These are, of course, all matters of particular difficulty for women, who have a particular need for part time work, a need for flexibility in the hours they work and, indeed, in the days that they work. These again are matters which the Opposition fully appreciates, and has acknowledged in our industrial relations policy. A central element of that policy is the making of voluntary agreements so that people will not be hidebound with the sort of rigid working times, hours, days and so on which are a feature of the excessively bureaucratic awards of our arbitration system and which in many cases are quite unsuited, particularly to women in employment. In our policies they will be given a very much greater opportunity to meet these obvious concerns they have about the nature of employment conditions, hours of work and so on. The vital importance to so many women of part time work is another matter which is acknowledged in our policy and which will be included in the industrial relations system on our return to government.

There are many other matters, and I do not propose to go through all of them, but in selecting these concerns at random, as I am, it is quite noticeable how many of the concerns of women expressed in these consultations are not the concerns of the strident feminists which the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, and numbers of other Labor senators in this place seem to emphasise. They are the real concerns of Australian women. Certainly the value of these consultations has been to reveal how very wide are the concerns of women, and they are not just the concerns of the strident feminist that we hear so much about from those on the other side of the chamber.

Another matter of concern which particularly interests me is that which has identified the numbers of women who are living in poverty, simply because they are single parents who have to rely on supporting parents benefits and with inadequate maintenance payments. This is also a problem in two-parent families where there is only a single income and when that income is low. We on this side of the chamber have been emphasising for some years the importance of adequate means of assessing maintenance, ensuring that proper maintenance is assessed and paid and is collected and received by the custodial parent. We know that the Government has only just made a new-found recognition of this.

I can remember moving in this chamber amendments to the Family Law Act in 1983, 3 1/2 years ago. I sought to amend that Act in order to improve the position of single parents, mainly women, who are not receiving inadequate maintenance because they have been shoved on to the taxpayer by the deliberate policy of Labor governments, particularly as a result of the philosophy of the late Senator Murphy with his Family Law Act which transferred that responsibility from the non-custodial parent to the state. Every one of the Labor senators who were here in 1983 voted against my amendment. I introduced a Bill at the end of 1985 to do the same job probably in a slightly more detailed way, and 12 months ago Senator Gareth Evans-who is now wandering in and out; we do not know where he is or he does not know where he is, as usual-told us that the Government opposed that Bill. Last week, the day after the Government found its new philosophy that there was a problem of single parent women in poverty, the Bill was brought on again for debate in this chamber, and they got up one after another to talk it out to avoid voting on it again. What a sorry record. What a sorry record the Labor women senators have had on this matter, in company with their male colleagues.

This statement that has been put down, this report of the consultations on the National Agenda for Women, is of great interest to the Opposition because it reveals clearly that the vast majority of women in Australia have the same concerns as we have and they want policies addressed to those concerns-policies which are far more in line with the thinking of the Opposition than with that of the Government, despite all the protestations and all the talk by Senator Ryan and others. I have spoken already about some of the real achievements of the Opposition when in government in relation to these matters. I wish to indicate that as far as the recognised status of women by political parties is concerned, it was a coalition government which first appointed a woman in Dame Enid Lyons to a Federal ministry. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who unfortunately does not seem to be with us this afternoon, was the first woman given a Cabinet portfolio. Her distinction is well known and recognised as Minister for Social Security and then as Minister for Finance. She was the first woman appointed to such a position and that appointment was made by a coalition government.

The Liberal Party has always recognised and encouraged women to take high office in the Party. Several state presidents of the Liberal Party have been women. The present Victorian State president is a woman. We have a very live understanding and recognition of the importance of the status of women, not that they should be in the home, as Labor senators would like to have people believe, but that they should have a full role in the community, whether it be on a voluntary basis or on the highest professional basis. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle came into this latter category as the first woman Cabinet Minister in Australia. Many other women on our side of politics will achieve status of that kind and, I venture to suggest, far earlier than women on the Labor benches. There are probably no more conservative, anti-feminist groups in this community than the unions of Australia. That is why all these awards that I have talked about are being tailored for men and not for women. The women want flexibility in employment and they will get it under the policies of the Opposition when it is returned to government. This is a valuable report because it tells us in the clearest terms, perhaps for the first time, what the women of Australia really need. Certainly, their needs and aspirations will be very well met by the policies of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I find it rather extraordinary, not to say a trifle pathetic, to listen to Senator Durack trying to regain some of the ground that was lost by the Liberal Party of Australia last week in the deplorable display that it turned on in relation to the Government's equal opportunities legislation when it preferred to kow-tow to the multi-untalented members of the National Party of Australia rather than put into effect its avowed support for the women of Australia. For many years now, we have been arguing for equality of opportunity in the work force, for equal treatment under the law, and for attention to be paid to the needs of women in a wide range of areas, and this report simply articulates those same views that have been argued by us for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The special importance of this document is that it actually quotes, as well as reflects, the concerns and aspirations of Australian women from a very wide range of age groups, ethnic groups, occupational areas and educational backgrounds. I suggest that their views are at least as important to governments-or should be-as those of any other group in the community. Indeed, I suggest that they are probably more important than the views of most groups that governments have a tendency to listen to because they reflect far more the real problems of society, the grass roots problems that affect Australian families at all income levels, in all social groups and in all ethnic groups. Women are a very important, constantly overlooked and frequently underrated element in Australia's social and economic well-being. To have in front of us the comments of ordinary women with the same sorts of aspirations that many of us have and have argued for, is particularly pertinent, very relevant and long overdue.

This document should be regarded as a valuable tool for government in the coming months and years. In the main the women whose views are expressed in this report are not speaking from vested interests, at least not the sort of vested interests that union and business representatives so often put forward. Instead these women are speaking out because of a genuine and well-founded concern about the lost opportunities, the discrimination, the violence, the stress and frustration that have faced them for many years and have continued to face them and their families in Australia in the 1980s. The issues that they raise through this report range from child abuse to child care. They relate to women's special health needs, their educational needs, the special problems facing rural, aged and migrant women, the difficulties facing women living below the poverty line following a marriage breakdown, for example, the resentment they feel at the low status given to the work done by women in the home, and the discrimination still facing women in the work force. Also they are concerned about the need for affordable housing, about women's treatment before the law and women's views about the environment and peace. All these matters are picked up in this document. Thus, the value and importance of the report come very largely from the contributions made the women themselves. These are not reports of what women want but statements by women themselves about what they want. The despair and the anger, as well as the hope that things might change, comes through very clearly in this document.

The Minister's statement recognises this contribution made by the women represented and quoted in the report before us, and acknowledges the report's importance. But unfortunately too much of it is simply rhetoric and far too frequently we have seen this Government's actions run counter to the needs of women and contrary to the Government's stated policies. Certainly they seem to run counter to the needs that are expressed in this report.

The delay in the normal November consumer price index increases to pensions last year, an action that was of course supported by Liberal and National Party senators, was, I would have thought, hardly the best way for this Government to have acted to help the aged and supporting parents, the majority of whom are women, get out of poverty and give their children and their families the standard of living to which they believe they are entitled. I would have thought that abolishing, even in a gradual form, the grant from the national community health program to the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia was hardly consistent with the Government's avowed intention of doing something to combat child abuse or to increase the status of women at home caring for children.

The Government argues on the one hand that it is concerned about recognising the value of the role played by women in the home and the importance of removing the sorts of stresses from families that lead to child abuse, yet the Nursing Mothers Association is deeply concerned that the counselling service it provides not just to nursing mothers and not just about breast feeding but to mothers with young children across the board, will be severely curtailed by the decision of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to curtail and finally, I think by 1990, cut out the funding to that Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is competition for those funds.

—Of course there is a lot of competition for those funds. Nobody is arguing about that, but this Association reaches a vast number of women in the community and it provides a telephone counselling service for volunteers not just about breast feeding but about how best to deal with the other problems that are regularly faced by women in the home. To deny funding to an organisation which deals with mothers from the time their children are born until the time the children are well developed is, I think, very much contrary to the Government's alleged purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The $250 tertiary education administration fee, as everybody knows from every bit of evidence, both empirical and anecdotal, will impact most on female students, particularly those from low income or migrant families which do not rate education for women particularly highly, and it will have a quite significant impact on women who are working part time or are caring for children and who want to study part time.

The Minister's statement finishes with a reference to the Government's equal opportunity legislation. I, like all thinking women and men in the community I would imagine, certainly welcome the initiatives that the Government has taken over the last few years through the Sex Discrimination Act, through the affirmative action legislation and through the legislation which was debated so appallingly-from some sides of the House anyway-in another place last week. However, I think it is worth repeating something which has been stated in this place time and again from a variety of senators-that access to employment opportunities according to merit only and not according to sex, marital status or any other rather irrelevant criterion can go only so far to ensure that women are able to avail themselves of this access. Without child care, without access to educational opportunities-either initial education opportunities or retraining opportunities-and without more flexible employment opportunities, all the equal opportunity legislation in the world will not get women into the work force in the numbers in which they would like to be there.

Sadly, I suggest, this Government has not so far shown that it is prepared to hear and minister to the needs of women and their families to the same extent that it hears and grants the demands of some male dominated groups and, in particular, business groups. How else can it explain abandoning the proposed maintenance collection system or the proposal from some quarters in the Government to means test family allowances? Surely members of the Government must be aware that studies by the Institute of Family Studies and others indicate that the income earned by the male breadwinner is not necessarily shared by the rest of the family in an equitable way and that to simply means test according to that criterion will significantly disadvantage a large number of women and their children. Yet the Government is apparently listening to those sorts of proposals as a result of the demands from business groups that the deficit be cut in any way in which it can be in order to placate overseas money markets and, presumably, get back our AAA rating.

Rhetoric is fine, but women in Australia are entitled to more than that. They are entitled not only to be consulted but also to be heard in the most meaningful way in which governments can hear people's concerns. To do anything else, I would have thought, is to be condescending as well as patronising. An awful lot of women in Australia, including me, expect far better than that from a Labor Government which has pledged itself to improving the opportunities for women in Australia. There is still far too much to be done, and the last chapters of this report indicate that. The portrayal of women in the media still leaves much to be desired, still emphasises stereotypes which are decades out of date. It is, as I said earlier, a fact that women, for a variety of reasons, are the group most concerned about peace and conservation, not only for their own sakes but also for the sake of their children, yet this Government is ignoring their pleas in continuing to do things such as selling uranium to France, allowing indiscriminate woodchipping and failing to protect many of the unique areas that Australia has to offer future generations. TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, said, the women of Australia were invited to have a say in the National Agenda for Women. SPEECH.PARA: We have the range of answers to the questionnaire. By far the majority-42 per cent-of the questionnaires, we are told, mentioned the women at home. So a total of 74 per cent of women, which is a very large number, aim for some type of work that fits in with their family commitments. Only 20 per cent of women chose full time employment. That is quite an amazing figure. This report has highlighted the fact that this is what women want.

Looking at the chapter on women in the paid work force we find that a total of 33 per cent noted work and employment as specific primary concerns. Employment conditions, including working hours and leave provisions, with the particular difficulties of women combining full time paid work with caring for a family were also the subject of considerable comment. In addition, women put forward varied views on affirmative action policies. Comments in `Setting the Agenda' underline what I have just cited from `Beyond the Stereotypes'. Let us look again at the section on women in the home. I will come back to the affirmative action section in just a moment. Very many women regarded affirmative action as a positive development, acknowledging the Government's intention to encourage policies to systematically identify and dismantle barriers to women's achievement.

I would call that-as I think would the majority of women-equal opportunity, not affirmative action, because affirmative action, as it is recognised throughout the world gives quotas for the numbers of women that should be employed in any one industry. It refers to numbers, actual quotas. Senator Ryan's report then goes on to state that there was little support for the imposition of quotas. So while the report says that women put forward varied views and very many women regarded affirmative action as a positive development, it notes that there was very little support for the imposition of quotas. It was considered that quotas would result in employment and promotion on grounds other than merit; that is, on the basis of qualifications, skills, experience and talent. The report states: `Some confusion was evident between quotas and objectives'. That is a value judgment about whether there was confusion. I will come back to that a little later.

In the child care area, overall, 29 per cent of women who responded to the questionnaire indicated that child care was one of the principal concerns. Again, that is a very relevant figure. Coming to the family allowance, we find that a significant number of participants called for the family allowance to be increased. Labor has not increased the family allowance at all in its term in office. When we were in office we increased it by 50 per cent. The dependent spouse rebate was increased considerably by us, from a maximum of $400 to a maximum of $1,030. This Government has not increased the dependent spouse rebate at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the promise to do so.

—Yes, despite the promise to do so by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his first election speech. He also promised that the family allowance would be increased. The Office of the Status of Women did market research in which 89 per cent of women regarded family allowances as important to them. This Government had a National Agenda for Women. It received 13,000-odd responses and it did not take any notice of the 89 per cent of women who want family allowances increased. That is the calibre of this report. The report obviously underlines the fact that family allowances should be increased. The Government, saying in the agenda that it is giving women a say, ignores that altogether. Chapter 7 is entitled `Violence against women and children'. There is considerable concern amongst mothers of Australia about the violence that goes on, particularly against their children. Chapter 8 is entitled `The dignity of women'. Again, overall, 28 per cent of the respondents to the questionnaire cited in the agenda identified the dignity of women as one of the top priority concerns. If we look through that chapter we come to the question of pornography and censorship. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The dignity of women can never be improved while pornography on paper and video and violence on video, film and television continues unchecked and freely available.
This concern-

. . . was echoed in many . . . submissions, and in concerns identified in responses to the questionnaire. Those women who commented on the relationship of pornographic materials to the dignity of women often called for the introduction of much stricter censorship standards.

It is of great concern to me that representatives of the Office of the Status of Women who came before the Joint Select Committee on Video Material refused to view the videos we were concerned about. We invited them to see some of them and they refused. They would not look at the videos we were referring to. Obviously, they had no idea what the Committee was referring to and now that comments have come from women all over Australia, perhaps they will agree to look at them because the Government must do something about them if it is sincere in any way in giving women a say as in the Agenda for Women of Australia.

What I was most interested in appeared on page 76-general comments regarding the economy. Unfortunately, we do not have a figure; the Minister has not given it to us. I would very much like to know what percentage of Australian women showed concern. It is just stated that many participants took part in the consultations. They took the opportunity to comment on issues related to economic policy. The Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women began its submission by drawing attention to the importance of economic policy to women. It said that economic policy has a direct bearing on the opportunities of Australian women and men in all walks of life. It shapes opportunities in employment, in business, our quality of life and the standards of community services we enjoy. It is no use the Government believing that women are interested only in child care, women's health, sport and recreation, their jobs, domestic violence and special needs. Page 8 of the Minister's statement reads:
The vote in the House of Representatives on the Equal Employment Opportunity Bill last week, however, has obviously called into doubt the Opposition's commitment in this very important area.

I will deal with that matter because I believe the Minister is not speaking accurately when she says that. The Government has been very clever, very smart, in introducing the two Bills into the Senate. In early 1986 the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill was introduced. The Government called the legislation affirmative action to satisfy the more radical feminists of its supporters. However, it was not an affirmative action Bill and the Opposition asked that the name of the Bill be changed to equal employment opportunity for women Bill. That was not done and affirmative action was maintained in the name of the Bill.

From 1 February 1987 the legislation applied to employers who had 1,000 or more employees; in 1988 it will apply to employers who had more than 500 employees and in 1989 it will apply to employers who have more than 100 employees. All those various companies had to do was submit a forward estimate which means a quantitative measure or aim which may be expressed in numerical terms and which is designed to achieve equality of opportunity for women in employment matters. It was a measure or aim that can reasonably be implemented by the relevant employer within a specific time. There was also an objective. So the legislation was not affirmative action; it was just a forward estimate or aim. An employer could give forward numbers if he chose but he did not have to give them; it was purely an aim. No direction was given to the Minister to force various employers to upgrade their aim or indeed to upgrade numbers if they chose to put forward numbers. There was nothing like that. That is the first Bill that came before us in 1986-the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill.

What has the Government done? The Government has just put through the House of Representatives another Bill which relates to Commonwealth authorities. What has it called the legislation? It is called Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill 1987 but without a doubt it is an affirmative action Bill requiring numbers and quotas-figures that the National Agenda for Women has said that women do not want. There is little support for affirmative action; there is little support for quotas; there is little support for numbers. Yet the Government has just introduced the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill under a fictitious name. This time the legislation should be called affirmative action legislation, but it is not. It is called equal employment opportunity legislation and states that Commonwealth authorities must set the quantitative, that is numbers, and other indicators against which the effectiveness of the program is to be assessed. So the legislation requires figures, numbers, quotas. It states:
to assess the effectiveness of the program by comparing statistics and information collected . . .
So this legislation is a true affirmative action program; it is a true affirmative action Bill. The legislation also states that the responsible Minister may direct the Commonwealth authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the principle of merit? You don't want to answer that. You won't answer that.

—I will come to that matter in a moment. The Bill states that the responsible Minister in respect of a relevant authority which has elected to lodge reports with the Minister may in writing give general direction to the authority with respect to the performance of its obligations under the Act. So we have an affirmative action Bill called the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill which allows the Minister to direct Commonwealth authorities to increase their numbers if he does not think the quotas are correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation does not deal only with women; it deals with a whole designated group of people. As I have said, it deals not only with women but also with Aboriginals and their families, with Torres Strait Islanders and their descendants, with migrants whose first language is not English, with the mentally and physically handicapped and with other designated groups that have not yet been put forward by the Government but no doubt it will decide upon them by regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet it doesn't deal with you.

—I am sure it does not. This Bill is misnamed; it is called equal employment opportunity legislation whereas it is true affirmative action legislation demanding numbers. The previous Bill, which was called affirmative action legislation, did not require numbers and it was really equal employment opportunity legislation. Both Bills have a covering clause which states that one should appoint people on merit. That applied to the first Bill because an employer did not have to achieve certain numbers; he just had a general aim. So one could legitimately say that the employment of people would be on merit. However, when an employer has to put forward a figure and when the Minister can direct the Commonwealth authority to increase that figure, that quota, merit flies out the window. If a Commonwealth authority said that it would employ an extra, say, 50 women and, come a direction from the Minister that he wanted the figure increased to 55, how on earth would merit come into it? The Commonwealth authority must obey the Minister and it must stick to the numbers-that is stated in the Bill-but now the Government is talking about merit and that, of course, is a lot of rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also talked about the fact that maintenance payments were a concern of women expressed in the questionnaire. In 1983 the Opposition put up a private member's Bill seeking to take out of the Family Law Act the requirement presently in that Act that a judge, when deciding on maintenance, must take into consideration supporting parents' entitlements to a taxpayer-supplied benefit or pension for them. It is all very well for Senator Tate to look a little upset about this, but in 1983 he, along with Government members, voted against our private member's Bill. Not many months after that Senator Tate was saying in Tasmania that of course this provision must be taken out of the Family Law Act and was claiming the idea as his own. That was quite hypocritical because he had just previously voted against this measure when we had put it up. Now the Government is putting up this measure as its own policy, having previously, in 1983, voted against it when we put it up.

The main thrust of this statement of Senator Ryan does not touch the crucial part of what women want. Our industrial relations policy, indeed, does just that. We have said to the women of Australia, and to everyone else in Australia as well: `Available to you under our policy are flexible work hours, flexible conditions, job sharing, if you so desire-anything that you and your employer together come to an agreement about'. Under the Government there is no way that women can have flexible work hours because the unions will not permit it. The unions will not permit a group of women to come to an agreement with their employer so that they can have, say, just half an hour's lunch break and go home so that they are there when their kids come home from school. The unions will not allow it.

Indeed, this has already been pointed out very clearly by the unions in the Mudginberri dispute. What happened in the Mudginberri dispute? The employer and the employees came to an agreement on flexible work hours and on what income they wanted. They were in full agreement. The employees were doing a lot better; they were earning a lot more. They came to this agreement with their employer. And what did the union say? It said: `Not on your life. We did not organise it, and therefore you cannot come to a private agreement'. That is what we want to abolish in this country. The women of Australia have to be able to make their own arrangements with their employers to fit in with their family commitments. If the women of Australia want to take on some part time work they should be entitled to take on that part time work. They should not have to abide by union decrees which make them unable to set their priorities as they want. If they want to be home after work to fit in with their children coming home after school and it suits the employer, they ought to be able to do it. They ought not to have to abide by a union decree that says that all that is outside their capabilities and that the union does not approve of it.

There is so much in this report that has just been tabled. There is so much hypocrisy in the whole set-up of asking the women of Australia to help set an agenda. There is so much hypocrisy in the Government saying that it is asking women to help it set the agenda when 89 per cent of women asked for family allowance to be increased and the Government says: `It is not one of our priorities. We will not give you what you ask. Anything trivial, anything that is a little band-aid measure, yes. But don't ask us to give you what you see as your number one priority. You don't stand a ghost of a chance'.

Pornography is a matter that has been discussed in the Senate for many years. In 1984 there were significant changes which meant that there was a great deal more of this material in the country. Since that time a number of us have pressed for changes, particularly in the Australian Capital Territory. A Senate committee was set up to look into the impact of the changes on the admission of this material. It is a Committee which is dominated by Government members, and I am afraid I can conclude only that the Government has little interest in seeing that this topic is reported on and dealt with.

The dignity of women can never be improved while pornography on paper and video and violence on video, film and television continues unchecked and freely available.
Even now I would again say to the Government: `Do what you can do and ban it in the Australian Capital Territory, at least until such time as the parliamentary Committee reports'.

The next chapter is entitled `Women's health'. It indicates that 18 per cent of the women who responded to the questionnaire placed health as a high priority and concern. I suggest that perhaps 18 per cent of women is a fairly low figure when one looks at the reality of the way women regard health. Many of the women who might have responded are perhaps too elderly and were not in a position to comment. It is a very important and significant area for elderly women, especially perhaps elderly migrant women-women for whom English is not their first language and who suffer from the additional problem, when they are old, of not being able to use their new language in the way that they could when they were younger. I think that many of us are familiar with what occurs. It is an important and a pressing matter. Osteoporosis, a complaint from which women have suffered for a long time, is something which must have a very high priority on the Agenda. It is important that all possible steps are taken to see that women know what they can do to help themselves avoid that debilitating problem. Apart from the effect on a woman who suffers from it, what is the cost to the community of the implications of osteoporosis? It is an issue that needs to be raised frequently so that we finally get some solutions from research and so that we know exactly what it is, how it can be combated, and how women from a very early age can learn to help themselves avoid that problem when they are elderly. None of us wants to be a burden on our families because of broken bones and the consequences of osteoporosis in later life. I believe that all of us could do a great deal to help ourselves if we knew about the problem early enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the solution? Is it diet?

—Diet is one matter. Perhaps this is not the time to mention it, but it is suggested that plumper women have less problem with it than slimmer ones. Diet is part of it. It is not just a matter of calcium intake; it is more than that. Too much calcium taken unsupervised very likely can lead to other significant problems. It is not just a simplistic matter. It needs to be addressed, and I believe it can be.

SPEECH.PARA: Under chapter 10, which is headed `Other concerns', there is a portion entitled `General comments concerning the economy'. I join my colleagues who have said that income security is vital to any woman, especially when she has the responsibility for children. It is not necessarily vast sums of money that are needed, but security of the amount that she has, so that she can budget and organise her household in a way that provides security for her children. She is concerned about the state of the economy and the possibility of her children being able to obtain employment or get into a tertiary institution. She is concerned about the cost of housing and the way in which housing repayments have risen in recent times. I have constituents in the Australian Capital Territory who are facing the prospect of having to sell their homes to get out of the financial mess that they are in as a result of high interest rates. In regard to the question of maintenance, which, of course, is very much concerned with income security-we did debate this matter last week-it is quite clear that something needs to be done. I regret that the Government did not take the opportunity to support the changes that could have been made last week when the matter was debated by the Senate. I hope that it will not put it off for too long.

As we are short of time today, I conclude on this point: On the matter of finance and income security, and the consequences of financial worries and stress, which causes marriage breakdown and despair, I received a letter not long ago from a woman. I will read part of it:

It seems to me not only unjust but absurd that a family such as ours can possibly be driven by despair over financial matters to a point of separation before we qualify for affordable housing. If I take the children-
and there are five of them-

and leave my husband, I know that not only will I have access to a supporting parent pension, but also to a Government house. This letter and the attached information is an attempt to prevent that possibility from becoming a reality.

There is much more in this letter. The issue is a very deep and involved one and there are many other aspects of it. I hope that the Government will give us the opportunity to debate it in full, that it will address the real issues that are of great consequence to women and their families, and that it will see that the plight of some of them which exists at present will be alleviated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this report of the consultations on the National Agenda for Women 1986 entitled `Setting the Agenda' particularly interesting, if only due to the fact that in its initial stages it states much that is obvious, and much with which we would not disagree. However, there are certain areas in which it is light on the ground. Not least of those areas is the statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). She asserted that the Opposition had changed its direction in terms of its policy on equality of opportunity and equality of employment opportunity. That is quite clearly incorrect. We have never at any stage opposed any proposition put forward for equality of opportunity generally, or equality of opportunity in employment specifically. Women do need a fair go, and we have recognised that for a long time. By the same token, we will not say that women need a fair go in isolation from other members of the community. This community is made up of men, women and children, and all should be given a fair go. As Senator Harradine mentioned by way of interjection a little earlier, there is nothing in this report which addresses the problems of youth. Those young people in Australia today who are struggling not only to find jobs but also to make ends meet, to carve a career for themselves and to make a future of stability, are not even considered in this report. That concerns me greatly.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, we have never sought to discriminate against anybody. We have always maintained a very firm and unequivocal position in saying that women need a fair go, men need a fair go, the youth of Australia need a fair go, regardless of their race, regardless of their age, regardless of sex, and so on. We have not veered away at any time from the basic merit principle. I shudder to think what will happen when we do veer away from that merit principle, because that merit principle is all important, regardless of sex, regardless of age, regardless of race, and regardless of any form of incapacity. It worries me when we have before us proposals to be debated at a a later date in which quite clearly the merit principle is mentioned, but, added to that, there is ministerial intervention and a measure is to be taken on a statistical basis of success or lack of it. We must stick purely and simply to the merit principle. Aims and objectives are fair enough, but when we start to dictate, either via legislation or via ministerial intervention, we are getting on to very dangerous ground.

The Government, as is stated in this report, wants more work based child care. I ask: At whose cost? It wants flexible working hours. As my colleague Senator Walters said earlier, we do not oppose the creation of more flexible working hours; it is just a jolly shame that the unions will not allow it. We have seen example after example in State after State in which women have made those arrangements with their employers because they consider it particularly important that they are at home when their children arrive home. I too consider that that is very important, having regard to the increasing number of juvenile delinquents as the years go by and the problems that children can get into that are far more readily available to get into than they were in my day. I would do everything possible to encourage mothers to be at home when their children get home-if not to pick them up from school. Too often we hear of children being abducted between school and home. I think that we as legislators should be looking very carefully at providing every possible opportunity to make sure that young children and young adolescents have as much supervision as possible.

The document talks about the provision of more maternity leave. I am not too sure who will pay for it, but the cost of the existing maternity leave provisions is enormous to the private sector, and the private sector, as we know, is being squeezed to death at the moment. It can barely breathe under the burden of the bureaucratic nonsense with which it has to deal today. But this statement is saying that even more restrictions are to be put on its operations.

The statement that women's achievements are played down or overlooked in the media is somewhat of a sad reflection, because some of the misguided positions taken by the strong feminists probably emanate from the fact that many successful women are not given enough publicity. These mad, radical feminists believe that there are no successful women, which is quite inaccurate to say the least. If such a move will change the course of the nation, which I doubt, I hope that the media will give women's achievements more recognition.

I found it interesting to see in the statement that schools have to be involved in teaching everything now, including child care, housework, nutrition, health and domestic finance. I thought that that was fairly sensible until I read the next proposition, which envisaged males in the next generation being capable of looking after families. I think that it is rather absurd to make such bland statements. Education in those areas is quite sensible, but if it is only to be directed at males so that they are to be capable of looking after families, it is an extraordinary proposition. Males used to be, and I think the majority still are, very capable of looking after families. They have not had formal education to do so. Since this is now to be a responsibility of schools, I would ask: Where does parental responsibility begin and end and where does the school take over. Most of those things-I speak not about the dim dark ages but more recently-have always been taught at home with assistance from the schools, but now we are getting to a position where the parents can abrogate their responsibility and hand it all back to the schools. Frankly, I do not have too much confidence in the schools being able to deliver the goods. We must make every opportunity for parents to be able to be responsible for the destinies of their own children, and bring back the bond between parents and children in preference to starting to say `Don't you worry about that'-as a certain gentleman has a great capacity to say in this country-`We will take the responsibility away from you and place it in schools'.

This is an interesting document, because it is the only Government document that acknowledges the low income of the rural sector and a need for rural families to receive assistance. Well, how about lowering the interest rates to start with? That would be of enormous assistance to the rural sector. But no, instead of that we are looking at band-aids on the bucket to provide more public money to people in strife. If we started looking at the positive ways of reducing hardship in rural areas, we would all be better off. There is real hardship in the rural community as there is in various areas of the business sector, but instead of looking at ways in which we can provide greater opportunities to people with less burdensome bureaucracy, where are we heading? We are heading for more and more government expenditure at a time when I was believing that this Government was attempting, even though it has failed in the past, to try to cut down government expenditure. This document clearly shows that government expenditure will not be cut but will be increased.

The document also states that young people, single people, supporting mothers, older people, rural people and working people are all living in poverty. Is it any wonder, because the Government policies of the day lack any ability for anybody to take any initiative to be a wealth creator, to be a person who is in a position to provide more employment for people? Why does not this Government, instead of making the bland statement that all these people are living in poverty, set about reducing taxation, looking at the family allowance position, which it promised to do and never did, looking at tax deductibility in certain areas pertaining to families, and looking at greater flexibility in working hours and acting on it? The Government should provide lower interest rates, reduce the inflation rate and provide greater educational options all within the existing framework. There is no great necessity for increased expenditure. The Government should provide some income security and affordable accommodation. We have all the infrastructure set up to be able to do all these things, yet they are not being done.

Clearly, judging by this document, women are still concerned about those basics of life, their security, employment prospects for their families generally, and want to be assured that they have a roof over their heads. There are many more positive steps that can be taken towards ensuring that women and people in the community generally, of all ages and of both sexes, have greater opportunity in what is being provided to assist them. I do not think this document goes to the core of the problem. It is fiddling around the fringes in preference to sitting down and saying: `These are the initiatives that we wish to take'. I hope that in the very near future the Government will look more closely at the positives, instead of the negatives which are overwhelming in this document.

—It is quite clear that there are two Ministers in this place who do not want the debate to go on tonight. SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

—As it is such an important matter I do intend to confine my remarks to the statement as far as possible. However, a report that is as weighty and substantial as this deserves more attention. SPEECH.PARA: When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced this National Agenda for Women and a survey back in November 1985, he said that there were three principles on which the whole subject would be based. These were: Giving women a choice, giving women a say and giving women a fair go. The coalition parties believe that those are all very worthy principles and we support them. Let us make it clear from the beginning that we are not arguing about the principles but we are arguing about a lot of things associated with this report and the Government's handling of women's affairs.

We believe that women should be able to have opportunities opened up for them. We believe that they should go into the next century with status equal to that of Australian men. Certainly this Government is giving women a say. There can be no doubt about that. If there is not one survey going on, there is another; there is a constant stream of surveys. Giving women a say is okay; it is in giving women a choice and a fair go that the Government is not succeeding. Let us remember some of the surveys. Last year it was announced that $100,000 would be spent over five years. That was granted for a study into the stress likely to be incurred from completing household chores, for goodness sake! If the Prime Minister has his little group of Ministers looking at wasteful grants, let them look at that one. Just imagine a five-year study of the stress involved in completing household chores! I could give the Senate a burst on that in five minutes. I have done 26 or 27 years of household chores; I think that I am expert in that field. Perhaps some senators opposite could do with a bit of education in that area.

Yesterday Senator Ryan announced another survey. What was that survey? Seven hundred and fifty households were to be surveyed on the extent and range of unpaid work done by women at home. That has been announced just after this report on setting the agenda. Why does the Government need to survey another 750 households about the unpaid work that women do at home or how women spend their time in a 24- or 48-hour period? It sounds like the McNair ratings-`Fill in your diary of what you did every minute for the last 24 or 48 hours'. The Minister said that this survey would provide useful information for planning of all sorts of things. She said that we would get sound statistical information on the way work in the home is undertaken. She is very concerned to learn something about work in the home. Perhaps it would be a jolly good idea if she went home and practised and gave this place away. Perhaps that is not a very kind thing to say, but I suggest that if she needs to spend all this Government money to find out about work in the home, she really should go home and do a bit of in depth research herself. As I have said, I do not believe that this Government is giving women a fair go. I do not believe that it is giving a choice.

The Minister in her statement said that she had some major concerns about areas relating to women. I wish to canvass just a few of those rather than keep Senator Tate too long from his electoral paper. Let us look at the question of education. We on this side of the chamber are concerned, as I am sure are many on the other side, that girls must have the same opportunities as boys to participate in and achieve in all areas and levels of study. Great steps have been taken in this country over the years and girls today are faced with a much greater choice than our mothers had. But just as important in providing equal opportunities for them is the task of encouraging them to participate in all areas that are open to them. We all know that in many cases the only real barrier to girls entering courses which lead to professions such as engineering or carpentry is their own unwillingness to do so. There is male domination of classes, there are teacher attitudes, there are the perceived employment prospects but, above all, girls are often influenced by their parents to take courses which prepare them for the traditional female roles. This Government says that it is concerned about the education of girls, and what does it do? It has imposed a $250 fee which puts part time women and single subject women out of the opportunities for education.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is a part time woman?

—Part time women students. I thank the honourable senator; I am glad she corrected me. Her Government has managed to put these women out of the educational running. They are trying to improve their qualifications, trying to get out of the poverty traps. They are not all on welfare. Many of the women who are trying to get this part time education are not on welfare. They are dependent on a husband's maintenance or earnings. They need their income for themselves, and the Government is not giving them any help at all. It is no good paying the Australian Capital Territory teachers their $250 fee and not helping women who are studying part time, struggling along on their own. Let us not forget those nurses, who have to compete in a very tertiary-oriented occupation from now on, who were trained under the hospital system. The Government does not give them any help, but it pays teachers in the Australian Capital Territory to improve their qualifications while they are getting wages from the Government. Australian women are concerned about their sons and daughters not getting into tertiary institutions. There is an aspect of education to be concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also said that she was concerned about employment. So are we. What about the jobs for these women? What about the jobs for these women's children? That is what we are concerned about in the area of employment. The Minister seems to think that if we bring down legislation we deal with the problems of women in employment. Of course, we do not. Employers have to be educated, not compelled, away from an attitude against women employees. The most effective way for employers to learn about the qualifications of women is to learn from women themselves. If they are appropriately educated, if they are capable, if they are confident in their abilities, they will themselves bring about change, in a far more permanent way than legislation ever could.

Affirmative action legislation will increase the number of women in the work force in the short term but long term change will be brought about only by their performance. We cannot afford to rely on legislation to give us equal opportunity; we cannot expect to get the job because of our sex. Let us beware of the decision that was made in the United States of America last week. Women who succeed want to be able to take pride in their own achievements, achievements which they have gained through their own attainments and drive. We cannot allow this sense of achievement to be denied us by quota systems and the like. I do not believe that women want jobs at the expense of their self-esteem. Women who are appointed through quotas and who fail at their jobs jeopardise the future opportunities for other women.

The Government denies that it is introducing quotas, but the setting of `quantitative and other indicators' for assessment, and the comparing of statistics for effectiveness assessment, are only a euphemism for a quota. Let there be no doubt about it; that is what is happening with the legislation before the chamber now. Equal opportunity is supported by the coalition parties, but quotas and unnecessary regulation of business are not acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this speech?

—The end does not justify the means, and if the honourable senator opposite does not know that he had better learn quickly. Businesses that go broke do not employ anybody, male or female. Let us be very clear about that. It is this Government that is sending businesses broke throughout Australia.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask Senator Newman to ignore the interjections and to direct her remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, Mr President. I will be very happy to speak to you. You are obviously much more receptive than some of those opposite. I think the Government should be looking very much more closely at the high level of bankruptcies in this country, as was mentioned earlier today. It is very clear that the mismanagement of the economy by this Government is directly responsible for many jobs being lost. It is this area of jobs that we are concerned about, not whether women have to be put into jobs by artificial means. Let us get the economy right, let us get interest rates down, let us get taxes down, let us get the regulation of business down, then let us get employment up.
—Vote Labor.

—If people voted Liberal we would not be in the mess we are in. It is because they voted Labor that we are in this hole. Another subject of concern to the Minister was women in the home. I am very glad that she considered that it was a matter of concern, apart from something to be studied.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 421, the order related to repetition. I suggest that if the speaker is not pulled up we will all be suffering repetitive stress injury from listening to her.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. If the honourable senator is not capable of learning and if he is finding it boring, perhaps he would be better to leave. However, maybe he is teachable and perhaps, therefore, it might be worth his while staying.
—He is a slow learner.

—Perhaps it is that he is a slow learner. The trouble today is that women do not truly have the choice of being women in the home. Women who have small children and who would dearly love to be in the home are being forced by this Government out into the work force. They are being forced because they cannot keep up with the cost of living that has been caused by this Government's mismanagement of the economy. This Government, over a four year term, has made no attempt to do anything about the dependent spouse rebate and no attempt to do anything about family allowances. Its only defence is simply to keep referring to years gone by. It has been in government now for four years and its record is rotten. The dependent spouse rebate is down 30 per cent in value from the time this Government came to office. The women of Australia do not need a survey to find that out. They know every week in their budgeting the net effect of having this Government in office. The Minister referred to a number of other matters. Because of Senator Tate's concern about the time, I do not want to canvass the entire report.
—Oh!

—I am very tempted to ignore Senator Tate, but I am concerned to give my colleagues an opportunity to speak on this matter before somebody brings down a gag. One of the matters which the Minister did not canvass very much at all was the question of housing. While I will not take the time tonight to talk about important matters concerning income security, health, advertising, violence and other such matters, I wish to pay a bit more attention to the question of housing. If there is one thing that is important to the women of this country it is how their families and themselves are housed. In this area, this Government's record is rotten. With high interest rates, with changes to investment guidelines and with changes to the taxation rules, we now have over 700,000 families below the poverty line after paying their rent or their mortgage costs. How is that for a record? Fancy going to an election on that! Young families throughout Australia are living in caravan parks. Young women are sleeping on park benches. Rents are going through the roof in the private rental market and, as a result, we have young couples who can neither buy a home, as they cannot take up the options of the first home owner's scheme because they cannot afford the rest of the money required, nor afford to rent on the private market-and we are expecting by 1990, which is only three years away, to have one quarter of a million families on the public rental waiting list. How is that for a record?
—Rotten.

—Rotten, yes. I would like to conclude by just drawing some of these strands together and saying that this National Agenda for Women, according to the Minister's statement, is going to be finalised later this year. This is a bit like the child maintenance situation. Honourable senators will recall that the Government started off with I think a Press release late last year about child maintenance.
—It all starts with a Press release.

—It all starts with a Press release, thank you very much. A little later we got a nice little glossy pink brochure all about child maintenance, and that canvassed the issues too. That was put out for a bit of discussion so that people could have their say, although a lot of people said that they were not given enough time to have their say. Then what do we get? We get a piece of paper wheeled up which says: `These are the things we think we will do, and these are the things we think we will look at doing'. Once again it was just a stalling tactic by the Government just to look as if it were doing something. There was very little substance in the latest piece of paper on the child maintenance program. That is exactly what seems to be the case here with the National Agenda for Women.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a whole lot of publicity back in 1985, and the Government has bubbled along with its agenda meetings ever since, here and there, particularly with some of the party faithful. Then this lovely glossy brochure was produced but nobody has managed to tell us yet at what cost to Australian taxpayers it was produced. Now the Minister says that this is all going to be looked at and that the agenda for women will be finalised later this year. In view of the fact that it has just been pushed into the agenda for today, it looks to me as though it is a government rushing to get a few things cleared away, and I just have to wonder why.

Let us make it clear that this is government by survey, it is government by Press release, it is government by glossy publications and it is government by `sell the story', but do not put too much substance in it. The Government says that we do not need to put too much substance in it. If it is trying to sell something to the Australian people, what is inside does not matter. The packaging is all. Of course there are useful, worthy and interesting things in here. Most of us knew all of them all along. How much did it cost to find that out all over again?

The women of Australia and all Australians are much more concerned about unemployment. They are much more concerned about the fact that this Government has got the place in a mess, that housing is unobtainable and that the family tax policies are just totally unacceptable. I say to this Government: Get the running of the country right. Then the Women of Australia might take it seriously. It has given them a say. Now it must give them a fair go.

After all the policy work that had been done, one would have thought it might have been able to sort out those priorities of policy. I conclude by simply saying that I look forward to seeing the Government's legislative response to the needs and concerns of Australian women, which are hopefully expressed in this report which I will read with great interest and pleasure.
